p: Studies have shown that the dose of liposomes used in vaccines can determine the types of immune response generated. Vaxfectin, which is a commercial liposome‐based adjuvant, induced strong humoral responses in mice when used at a high dose (900 µg) with trivalent influenza vaccine (TIV), while at 30 µg of Vaxfectin, antibody responses were not induced but the amount of interferon‐γ (IFN‐γ) secreting T cells was increased up to 18‐fold. 78 In agreement with this study, two other cationic lipid‐based adjuvants (DC‐Cholesterol and ceramide carbamoyl‐spermine) were also shown to enhance humoral responses at higher doses and cellular responses at lower doses. 71, 79 This immune‐modulatory property can be explored in influenza vaccine development to produce the required immune responses just by dose modifications.
